segments.text: But again, like I say, my whole two years was fighting in the north, but I was over there in 67, 68, 69, and 70.
That was the time of the heaviest fighting prior to 72 when they came across the border once the U.S. forces were gone.
We never lost a battle.
We inflicted major injury on the enemy.
I think if you – and I don't like to use the word body counting, though you probably read a lot about body count in Vietnam.
I wasn't involved in body count.
If you look at casualties, the American forces lost right around 56,000, maybe it's 58,000.
But they believe the North Vietnamese lost up in the 300,000 troops.
We just had a greater military might.
We had the ability to inflict massive destruction on the enemy any time we're in contact.
As a man, especially when I was flying OB-10s, where I was the tackle air controller airborne, and just to see the might that come down.
You get a troop of friendly forces in contact with the enemy.
Like I mentioned earlier, it was just a matter of seconds before, you know, artillery rounds, naval gunfire rounds.
At one time, I remember one time we had a Marine regiment that was fighting an NVA division.
I had 23 flights of fixed-wing stacked overhead.
I mean, that's the type of power we had.
So in answer to your question, I can say that mainly we...
I'm not aware of us losing any battles, but I would have to say overall we lost the war.
And I say we lost the war.
I don't think it's the American military that lost the war.
It's the American people that lost the war.
Because, number one, they didn't fight it right.
They just didn't fight it right.
And you have to blame that on the politicians.
And, of course, then once the war was going on, they had to—the reason we're out of there is because the American people said we don't want our military over there.
Sir, I'd like to thank you for your time.
That concludes this interview.
Okay.
Well, if you have any questions on Vietnam, I know it's a short interview.
